ParaBlock.RichText: As you know, the world of information technology has changed. Today, we are using sophisticated communication mediums, and sharing information like never before. We're able to relay, transmit, and process information quickly, thus the volume of data that is exchanged and stored has increased tremendously in the last few years. All of this data, some of it extremely sensitive, is at risk and needs to be protected. That is where cybersecurity plays a critical role.

In this course you will view cybersercurity through the eyes of a black hat hacker by detecting threats and vulnerabilities and outlining steps to make your organization's information and customers more secure.

In technology, security is a state in which information resides. It is a mechanism designed to provide a transparent layer of protection to your data. We cannot see security, but we can implement and maintain it through a series of steps, practices, recommendations, standards, and policies in organizations, but also at home. Security is applicable everywhere data exists.

It is important to understand some basic terms referring to cybersecurity.
Threat: A threat is a potential problem for our computers and networks. Many types of threats exists, from natural disasters to computer viruses, for example. The use of a USB key also represents a threat for computer systems, as we know portable devices can have backdoors and malware that can replicate within a system upon connection.
Vulnerability: A threat wouldn't have a chance at surviving if our computers were completely secure. However, this is far from reality, and for that reason, many weaknesses or vulnerabilities can be found. A weakness can exist because of unpatched software, a human error, or because of a misconfiguration that can lead to a confidentiality, integrity, or availability attack.
Attack: An attack is the process of taking advantage of a vulnerability that has been discovered on a particular system. It is typically happening at a specific time and fashion so attackers try to make it happen undetected. An attack is live, and many tools and technologies can exist to stop this phenomenon. Multiple attack vectors exist, mapped to vulnerabilities.
Exploit: An attack is launched based on a series of steps that are documented within an exploit. It is a staged process aiming at executing the attack, and providing a technical staging process on the execution itself.
Controls or countermeasures: Defense techniques aimed at blocking or altering an exploit so it fails and does not succeed.

Finding information related to a computer system or network is the first step in trying to take it over. Accessing public resources, or getting information on a network from insiders, is also a key component in identifying ways the system will be attacked, that is, what attack vector will be chosen to take over the system.
In this module, you will explore domain name information, internet protocol addressing, and discover local network resources.

QuestionStem.RichText: Match the word with the definition

ParaBlock.RichText: The discovery phase is the phase that will likely take the longest to accomplish, as an extensible database of information needs to be built. There are a variety of tools that can be used in discovery and the information you collect will help to identify the attack vectors. Check out the Discovery Tools handout for information and links for various discovery tools.

A computer network or data network is a telecommunications network which allows computers to exchange data. In computer networks, networked computing devices exchange data with each other using a data link. The connections between nodes are established using either cable media or wireless media

Topic.Title: Demo: Collecting Old Web Page Content

Movie.Title: Demo: Collecting Old Web Page Content

ParaBlock.RichText: Purpose/steps of the demo: - Browse to the http://archive.org/web/ page - Specify globalknowledge.com within the Browse History field - Take 2009 and date in March for the snapshot. Click to see the old Web page - Example/direct link: http://web.archive.org/web/20090310031707/http://www.globalknowledge.com/

Topic.Title: Demo and Activity: Finding Domains and IPs

Movie.Title: Demo and Activity: Finding Domains and IPs

ParaBlock.RichText:
- Browse to netcraft.com - Specify Globalknowledge.com into the what’s running section. - Click on the report for the www.globalknowledge.com result. - At that point, emphasis on the “Web server” column, explain that 7.5 represents a Windows Server 2008R2 type of system running behind the scene. - Other information such as the IP of the server can be mentioned to provide a more complete picture of what is being presented here.
It is possible to gather this information using the Netcraft tool. By typing the domain name in the What’s running tool, you get an array of information regarding the Web services of that company. Plus a lot more… Try this after the demonstration – type the domain name of a company and explore the report given to you by Netcraft.
In there, you will find the IP addresses of the hosting servers, as well as information regarding the domain name of the company.
Purpose/steps of the demo: - Browse to network-tools.com Website - Type globalknowledge within the search, and show the output. Take note of the IP address (206.195.131.240)
It is then possible to use Web utilities such as Network-tools.com to find out contact information regarding the domain, the IPs in use, as well as the network configuration of the company on the Internet.
Notice it is possible to perform a Whois (IP and domain related info), nslookup (DNS search), Trace (routing information), as well as a PING to discover the state of the remote resource you are exploring.
Purpose/steps of the demo: - Browse to the infosniper.net website. - Specify the IP address within the check field, and observe the physical location of the server hosting the globalknowledge.com Website.
If you would like to find out more regarding the location of the servers you find online, you can do so by mapping the IP address to a region using infosniper.net. It shows you the ISP, the location, as well as the computer name, if available.
Finally, we can also browse to the Shodan database to discover what kind of hardware a company might be running. Shodan is the first Internet of Things search engine, allowing you to discover many types of devices that are running worldwide (IP cameras, intelligent systems, appliances, etc.). Free registration is required to perform the data collection and information gathering.
Another possibility to find the operating system running on a computer is to launch tools such nas, NMap, SuperScan or IDServe. These tools are establishing a direct connection from your system to the target, while these that are Web-based are more passive, and do not leave a trace of your record. We will see how some of these utilities work later, as many are multi-functional, meaning they perform other interesting actions we can perform in the discovery process.

Purpose/steps of the demo: - Start-RUN-CMD - NBTSTAT –A (IP address of the Windows 7 system in the lab network) - Mention the types of services that are running, for example sharing services, workgroup membership…
It is possible to discover shares and the local neighborhood configuration. Although it is required to be inside of the network for this, utilities such as ShareEnum, or NBTSTAT take advantage of the NETBIOS protocol to get information about a system that is discoverable on the network. They often list more than enough when it comes to understanding what the system is doing on the network.
For example, the NBTSTAT –A command that provides results about services running on a remote system. Depending on the output, it is possible to discover the type of system, and some of its characteristics (workgroup name, MAC address, service name, etc.)
As you can see, I can discover information that is available for the Windows 7 computer on the network. System misconfigurations often result in key information revealed to the world. For example, a Web server inappropriately secured can reveal its back-end system, a mail server revealing the internal IP schema or server names, as well as some default configurations that allow a system to be discovered through a public Wi-Fi.
The discovery phase can be quite extensive to the level where you find and map network diagrams based on the network configuration, find live systems (commonly referred to as ping sweep), the points of entry from the Internet (a VPN server for example), the default routes, as well as the discovery of directory services, such as Active Directory. Most of these do not require an intrusive method, and are very often successful.

QuestionStem.RichText: Match the description to the appropriate discovery tool.

Match.RichText: Used to collect old Web content such as pages, videos, and programs
Used to gather information regarding the Web services of a company
A suite of online utilities designed to perform footprinting
Used to map an IP address to a physical location

QuestionStem.RichText: Which of the following is NOT true regarding discovery defensive measures?

Distractor.RichText: Domain names, as well as DNS information, should be specific

Option.Feedback: Try again. Default configurations should be changed as a defensive measure.
Try again. Disabling NETBIOS is an effective defensive measure.

ParaBlock.RichText: The CISO has asked you to “place yourself in the shoes of a ‘Black Hat’ and go through a few attack phases.” Discovery/Footprinting is the first attack phase and the discovery of the resources is one of the critical steps in Footprinting an organization. Your first objective involves the use of tools to find information about the company on the Internet and on the local network. The collected data will help us understand the exposure level the organization is currently having.

The CISO has asked you to “place yourself in the shoes of a ‘Black Hat’ and go through a few attack phases.” Discovery/Footprinting is the first attack phase and the discovery of the resources is one of the critical steps in Footprinting an organization. Your first objective involves the use of tools to find information about the company on the Internet and on the local network. The collected data will help us understand the exposure level the organization is currently having.
In this challenge you will… Explore domain name information Explore internet protocol addressing Discover local network/intranet resources
Use appropriate tools and report your findings. A list of tools to use, tasks to complete, and questions to answer can be found in your Discovery/Footprinting Report.
If you need help along the way you can get step-by-step instructions on how to find information to answer each question or watch the solution videos. I recommend trying to complete the challenge on your own or using the instructions if you get stuck. You will receive feedback on your report after you submit it. Good luck!

List.ListPreamble: You must find and record the following information:

Item.ItemPara: What is the domain name of Global Knowledge?
Is the domain name registered? If yes, who is the registrar, the company that registered the domain on behalf of Global Knowledge on the Internet?
What domain name servers are hosting the GlobalKnowledge.com zone?
What type of system is used to host Global Knowledge website?
What is the IP address of the DNS server DNS1.globalknowledge.com?
Using MXToolbox, find the server to which the email is relayed when you send to an @globalknowledge.com address?

List.ListPreamble: You must record the following information:

Item.ItemPara: Use PING (CMD icon) to determine what IP address www.globalknowledge.com is resolving to.
Use Infosniper (http://www.infosniper.net) to find out where the website is hosted geographically?

List.ListPreamble: You must record the following information:

Item.ItemPara: Use Advanced IP scanner (Advanced IP scanner icon) to determine the identity of the service that is running on 10.0.0.20. Beside the IP address and the name of some systems, what other information is revealed about the hosts that reside on the same network as the Windows 7 VM?
What is the name of the 10.0.0.20 system?
What is the name of the workgroup this system belongs to?
What is the result of a HTTP Get Request reporting about the server?

UserAction.ActionDescription: Upload your findings to get feedback on your work.

ParaBlock.RichText: We now see the importance of understanding what discovery is. In this module, we’ve started by understanding what attack vectors are, helping us understand that the first phase in their exploitation is to be able to find and identify resources on the networks. When a comprehensive list of these resources is acquired, it is possible to find the ones that represent an interest to attackers, particularly based on the types of services they are running. What attack vectors have you heard about in the news? What discovery prevention mechanisms does your organization use? Send any thoughts or questions you have about discovery and attack vectors to the instructor for feedback.

Item.ItemPara: What attack vectors have you heard about in the news?
What discovery defensive measures does your organization use?
Send any thoughts or questions you have about discovery and attack vectors to the instructor for feedback.

ParaBlock.RichText: Now that we have acquired key information regarding the topology and network posture of an environment, the next step is to understand more in depth the protocols and network applications running on systems. It is also ultimately important to start thinking about how the gathered information can be used to perform a real attack by finding vulnerabilities in the running services.

Now that we have acquired key information regarding the topology and network posture of an environment, the next step is to understand more in depth the protocols and network applications running on systems. It is also ultimately important to start thinking about how the gathered information can be used to perform a real attack by finding vulnerabilities in the running services. In this module, we will be covering the port scan and vulnerability scan phases – we’ll get a much better picture of the security by finding flaws in systems.

QuestionStem.RichText: Identify the type of scanner for each tool.

ParaBlock.RichText:
Now that we have an understanding of the systems present on our network, we will proceed further by scanning these systems to discover open ports. Then, we will focus on detecting vulnerabilities, and visualize comprehensive reports that will show weaknesses of a system.
In this challenge you will Scan systems to discover open ports Detect vulnerabilities
Use appropriate tools and report your findings. A list of tools to use and questions to answer can be found in your Vulnerabilities and System Scanning Report.
Remember, if you need help along the way you can get step-by-step instructions on how to find information to answer each question or watch the solution videos. Again, I recommend trying to complete the challenge on your own or using the instructions if you get stuck. You will receive feedback on your report after you submit it. Good luck!

Now that we have an understanding of the systems present on our network, we will proceed further by scanning these systems to discover open ports. Then, we will focus on detecting vulnerabilities, and visualize comprehensive reports that will show weaknesses of a system.

UserAction.ActionDescription: Scan systems to discover open ports

List.ListPreamble: Use Nmap to answer the following questions:

Item.ItemPara: What ports are open on the 10.0.0.25 computer?
What operating system is running on that system?
What is the name of the system?
What is the MAC address of the system?
Use Nessus to determine what system vulnerabilities exist on port 445 of the 10.0.0.25 computer?

ParaBlock.RichText: In this module, we discovered how port scans, as well as vulnerability scans work, and why these are necessary and part of the sequence an attacker would use to compromise a system. So far, with the discovery of information, and now having performed these scans, we are getting ready for the next phase, which is system exploitation. Which port and vulnerability scanning tools are most intriguing to you? Why? Which vulnerability and systems scanning countermeasures would be the easiest to implement? The hardest? Send any thoughts or questions you have about vulnerability and systems scanning to the instructor for feedback.

Item.ItemPara: Which port and vulnerability scanning tools are most intriguing to you? Why?
Which vulnerability and systems scanning countermeasures would be the easiest to implement? The hardest?
Send any thoughts or questions you have about vulnerability and systems scanning to the instructor for feedback.

ParaBlock.RichText: Congratulations! It's time to wrap up this course and look ahead to what's next.

Topic.Title: Course Summary, Application, and Next Steps

ParaBlock.RichText:
As we wrap up this course I invite you to summarize what you learned, apply what you learned, and ask questions to continue learning…
Summarize what you learned. What was the most important or relevant thing I learned? Why? How does what I learned fit in with what I already know? How is it new or different?
Apply what you learned. What will I apply from this experience? How will I apply what I learned? What can I reference to reinforce what I learned in order to apply it effectively? What additional knowledge or skills do I need to be able to apply it effectively?
Ask questions to continue learning. Think about the following types of questions when considering how you will continue to learn more. Ask questions of the instructor and receive answers and guidance. How do I…? When do I…? What should I do if…? Who should…?
Thank you for taking Introduction to Cybersecurity! Please complete the course evaluation so we can continuously improve the learning experience.
